classification.description: Strong tensions present - likely to act soon

executiveSummary:
**PULL Score: 65/100 (HIGH_CONSIDERATION)**

Sarah Chen (Head of Security) joined 45 days ago from Stripe. They have 45 days left in their "prove myself" window and are likely experiencing "ratio shock" - the gap between Stripe's mature security program and what exists here.

**The Dynamic:** Sarah Chen knows what good looks like. They're in a 30-day window to demonstrate value. They will champion a solution that helps them show quick progress.

champion.name: Sarah Chen
champion.title: Head of Security
champion.insight: Came from Stripe - experiencing ratio shock, knows the right solution

ratio.implication: Security team is stretched - efficiency gains would help

leadership.implication: Sarah Chen (Head of Security) is in prove-myself window with 45 days remaining. Came from Stripe - experiencing "ratio shock" and knows the right solution.

growth.implication: Department falling behind - needs force multipliers

resource.implication: series b company in deployment phase - investor pressure to professionalize operations and show traction

reporting.implication: Security reports to CTO - Technical excellence, engineering productivity, platform reliability. Likely objection: "Can we build this ourselves? Does it integrate well?"

windows.description: Sarah Chen's 90-day window closes in 45 days
Post-funding deployment phase - capital available, pressure to show progress
Use it or lose it - get this approved before year end

primaryWindow.description: Sarah Chen's 90-day window closes in 45 days

stakeholders.objection: Can we build this ourselves? Does it integrate well?

behavioralPatterns.description: New leaders anchor on their previous company's approach
behavioralPatterns.application: Sarah Chen will anchor on Stripe's approach
behavioralPatterns.tactic: Reference how Stripe or similar companies handle this

behavioralPatterns.description: Pain of loss is 2x stronger than pleasure of equivalent gain
behavioralPatterns.application: Frame around what they lose by not acting, not just what they gain
behavioralPatterns.tactic: Quantify the cost of inaction: "Every month without SOC 2 is X enterprise deals at risk"

behavioralPatterns.application: Only 45 days left in Sarah Chen's action window
behavioralPatterns.tactic: Emphasize the closing window: "To show results before your 90-day mark..."

primary.message: Technical excellence, engineering productivity, platform reliability

secondary.message: Quick win for your first 90 days - show security progress without adding headcount

pitchAngle.openingAngle: "As the new Head of Security, what's your biggest priority in the first 90 days?"

objections.objection: Can we build this ourselves? Does it integrate well?

objections.response: Calculate eng time cost vs. tool cost. "Your engineers cost $200/hr - is compliance their best use?"

rationale: Sarah Chen's 90-day window closes in 45 days
High buying probability - direct approach warranted

internalDialogue:
# INTERNAL MEETING SCENE

**SETTING:** Nike's main conference room, Tuesday 2:47 PM. Sarah Chen sits across from David Kim (CTO) for their bi-weekly check-in. Sarah has a notebook filled with metrics and a laptop showing compliance spreadsheets.

**SARAH:** David, I wanted to walk through our SOC 2 timeline. Based on what I'm seeing, we're looking at 12-18 months if we continue manually collecting evidence and managing controls.

**DAVID:** [Thinking: That seems long, but Sarah knows this stuff] Okay, break that down for me. What's driving that timeline?

**SARAH:** [Internal panic: I have 45 days left to prove I can handle this role] Right now we have two engineers spending about 60% of their time just on evidence collection. Screenshot compliance, manual policy updates, chasing down access reviews. At Stripe, our security-to-engineer ratio was about 1:12. Here we're at 1:25, and that gap is showing. [Thinking: I can't say "we're behind every benchmark I know" but we really are]

**DAVID:** [Thinking: She keeps referencing Stripe. I need to know if she can work with our constraints, not just compare us to a public company] Look, I get that you had more resources there, but we're series B. We need to be scrappy. Can't we build some automation ourselves? Maybe a simple dashboard that pulls from our existing tools?

**SARAH:** [Thinking: Here's the engineering mindset - build vs buy. But I've seen this movie] I ran those numbers. Custom building would take Marcus and Jenny about 4-5 months just for basic evidence automation, and that's assuming no other security incidents. Then we still need ongoing maintenance, integrations with new tools as we scale... [Pausing] And honestly, that timeline puts my SOC 2 commitment to the board at risk.

**DAVID:** [Thinking: Board commitment. That's the real pressure here] What kind of risk are we talking about?

**SARAH:** [Internal stress: This is my prove-it moment] The Q4 enterprise deals Lisa's team is chasing - three of them explicitly mentioned SOC 2 as table stakes. If we push this to Q2 next year, that's potentially $2M in delayed revenue. [Thinking: I know the solution exists, I just need him to see we can't DIY our way out of this one]

**DAVID:** [Thinking: Now we're talking business impact, not just security nice-to-haves] So what are you proposing?

**SARAH:** I've been researching compliance automation platforms. Something that can integrate with our current stack, automate the evidence collection, and give us continuous monitoring instead of these manual point-in-time assessments. [Thinking: Please don't ask me to build this from scratch when specialized tools exist] The ROI is pretty clear when you factor in the FTE time we'd save plus faster time to compliance.

**DAVID:** [Thinking: She's learned to speak in ROI, that's good. But I need to know this integrates well and doesn't create technical debt] Show me the technical specs on what you're evaluating. I want to make sure whatever we choose plays nicely with our existing infrastructure and doesn't become another vendor management headache.

**SARAH:** [Thinking: He's moving from "if" to "what" - that's progress] Absolutely. Let me put together a technical evaluation with integration requirements and we can review later this week?

**DAVID:** Do it. And Sarah? Include the comparison to building internally. I need to justify this to the board as the right technical decision, not just the fast one.
